title: 114_s566
content: The Act may be cited as the "Tropical Forest Conservation Reauthorization Act of 2015" and includes a table of contents. The "Tropical Forest Conservation Reauthorization Act of 2015" includes provisions for protection of forests and coral reefs, eligibility for benefits, United States Government representation on oversight bodies, conservation agreements, a Conservation Fund, changes to due dates of annual reports, International Monetary Fund criterion for country eligibility, and authorization of appropriations for debt reduction. Sec. 12 authorizes appropriations for debt reduction and expenses related to audit, evaluation, monitoring, and administration. SEC. 2 amends the title of the Tropical Forest Conservation Act to the Tropical Forest Conservation Reauthorization Act of 2015. Any references to the previous act in other laws will now refer to the new act. SEC. 3 focuses on the protection of forests and coral reefs. The Tropical Forest Conservation Reauthorization Act of 2015 is amended to include protection for non-tropical forests and coral reef ecosystems. The importance of protecting these areas is emphasized throughout the amendments. The Tropical Forest Conservation Reauthorization Act of 2015 is amended to include protection for non-tropical forests and coral reef ecosystems. The amendments emphasize the importance of safeguarding these areas. The Tropical Forest Conservation Reauthorization Act of 2015 is amended to include protection for non-tropical forests and coral reef ecosystems. The amendments define coral as species of the phylum Cnidaria, including various orders such as black corals, stony corals, soft corals, and others. The Tropical Forest Conservation Reauthorization Act of 2015 now includes protection for non-tropical forests and coral reef ecosystems. Coral is defined as species of the phylum Cnidaria, including various orders such as black corals, stony corals, and soft corals. A coral reef is defined as any reef or shoal primarily composed of coral, while a coral reef ecosystem includes the coral reef and surrounding coastal marine ecosystems important for maintaining ecological integrity. SEC. 4 of the Tropical Forest Conservation Reauthorization Act of 2015 changes the name of the facility from "Tropical Forest Facility" to "Conservation Facility". This change is also reflected in definitions and references throughout the Act. SEC. 5 amends eligibility for benefits under the Tropical Forest Conservation Reauthorization Act to include non-tropical forests and coral reefs. SEC. 6 addresses United States government representation on oversight bodies for grants from debt-for-nature swaps and debt buybacks. Section 808(a)(5) of the Tropical Forest Conservation Reauthorization Act of 2015 is amended to allow individuals appointed by the United States Government to serve on the administering body overseeing grants from debt-for-nature swaps or debt buybacks, regardless of the U.S. being a party to any agreement. The Tropical Forest Conservation Reauthorization Act of 2015 is amended to rename agreements from "tropical forest agreement" to "conservation agreement" and eliminate the requirement to consult with the Enterprise for the Americas Board. The role of beneficiary countries is also revised. The Tropical Forest Conservation Reauthorization Act of 2015 is amended to allow the government of the beneficiary country to request funding for projects that improve governance and management of forests or coral reef ecosystems. Grants over $250,000 must be approved by both the US and the beneficiary country's government. In subsection (d), the Tropical Forest Conservation Reauthorization Act of 2015 is further amended to include non-tropical forests and coral reef ecosystems in addition to tropical forests. The amendment also specifies that projects must be consistent with conserving resources in these ecosystems. The Tropical Forest Conservation Reauthorization Act of 2015 is amended to include non-tropical forests and coral reef ecosystems. Section 803(7) is amended to replace "Tropical Forest Agreement" with "Conservation Agreement". SEC. 8. CONSERVATION FUND. Amendment to the Tropical Forest Conservation Reauthorization Act of 2015 includes changing the name from "tropical forest fund" to "conservation fund" and updating references to "Tropical Forest Agreement" to "Conservation Agreement." Definitions in the Act are also amended to reflect these changes. The amendment changes references from "Tropical Forest Fund" to "Conservation Fund" in various sections of the Act. SEC. 9 repeals the authority of the Enterprise for the Americas Board to carry out activities under the Tropical Forest Conservation Authorization Act of 1998. SEC. 10 changes the due dates of annual reports to Congress. SEC. 10 amends the Tropical Forest Conservation Reauthorization Act of 2015 by changing the due dates of annual reports to Congress to April 15 and replacing "fiscal year" with "calendar year." SEC. 11 amends the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 regarding the International Monetary Fund criterion for country eligibility. It removes certain conditions and emphasizes the implementation of sound macroeconomic policies. SEC. 12 authorizes new appropriations for debt reduction and audit, evaluation, monitoring, and administration expenses. Section 806 of the Tropical Forest Conservation Reauthorization Act of 2015 is amended to allocate $20,000,000 for fiscal years 2015 to 2018. Additionally, $300,000 is authorized for audits, evaluations, monitoring, and administration of programs under this part.
